questions.question: A circle has radius <math><mn>6</mn></math>. What is the circumference of the circle, in terms of <math><mi>π</mi></math>?
questions.explanation: The circumference of a circle is <math><mi>C</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn><mi>π</mi><mi>r</mi></math>. Substituting <math><mi>r</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>6</mn></math> gives <math><mi>C</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn><mi>π</mi><mo>(</mo><mn>6</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>12</mn><mi>π</mi></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Memorize key circle formulas such as <math><mi>C</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn><mi>π</mi><mi>r</mi></math> and <math><mi>A</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>π</mi><msup><mi>r</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></math>.

questions.question: A circle has diameter <math><mn>10</mn></math>. What is the area of the circle, in terms of <math><mi>π</mi></math>?
questions.explanation: The radius is half the diameter, so <math><mi>r</mi><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mn>10</mn><mn>2</mn></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mn>5</mn></math>. The area of a circle is <math><mi>A</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>π</mi><msup><mi>r</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></math>, so <math><mi>A</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>π</mi><msup><mn>5</mn><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>=</mo><mn>25</mn><mi>π</mi></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Convert diameter to radius before using <math><mi>A</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>π</mi><msup><mi>r</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></math>.

questions.question: Which equation represents a circle with center <math><mo>(</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>,</mo><mo>-</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>)</mo></math> and radius <math><mn>4</mn></math>?
questions.explanation: A circle with center <math><mo>(</mo><mi>h</mi><mo>,</mo><mi>k</mi><mo>)</mo></math> and radius <math><mi>r</mi></math> has equation <math><msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mi>h</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>y</mi><mo>-</mo><mi>k</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>=</mo><msup><mi>r</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></math>. Here <math><mi>h</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn></math>, <math><mi>k</mi><mo>=</mo><mo>-</mo><mn>3</mn></math>, and <math><msup><mi>r</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>=</mo><msup><mn>4</mn><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>=</mo><mn>16</mn></math>, giving <math><msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>y</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>=</mo><mn>16</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: In <math><msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mi>h</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>y</mi><mo>-</mo><mi>k</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>=</mo><msup><mi>r</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></math>, the center is <math><mo>(</mo><mi>h</mi><mo>,</mo><mi>k</mi><mo>)</mo></math> and the radius is <math><mi>r</mi></math>.

questions.question: A circle has circumference <math><mn>18</mn><mi>π</mi></math>. What is the radius of the circle? Enter your answer as an integer.
questions.explanation: Use <math><mi>C</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn><mi>π</mi><mi>r</mi></math>. Set <math><mn>18</mn><mi>π</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn><mi>π</mi><mi>r</mi></math>. Divide both sides by <math><mn>2</mn><mi>π</mi></math> to get <math><mi>r</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>9</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: When solving for <math><mi>r</mi></math>, cancel <math><mi>π</mi></math> early in <math><mi>C</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>2</mn><mi>π</mi><mi>r</mi></math> to simplify.

questions.question: A sector of a circle has radius <math><mn>8</mn></math> and central angle <math><mn>135</mn><mo>°</mo></math>. What is the area of the sector, in terms of <math><mi>π</mi></math>?
questions.explanation: The area of a sector is the fraction of the full circle area: <math><mfrac><mi>θ</mi><mn>360</mn></mfrac><mo>·</mo><mi>π</mi><msup><mi>r</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></math>. Here <math><mi>θ</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>135</mn></math> and <math><mi>r</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>8</mn></math>, so the area is <math><mfrac><mn>135</mn><mn>360</mn></mfrac><mo>·</mo><mi>π</mi><msup><mn>8</mn><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mn>3</mn><mn>8</mn></mfrac><mo>·</mo><mi>π</mi><mo>·</mo><mn>64</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>24</mn><mi>π</mi></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: For sector problems, compute <math><mfrac><mi>θ</mi><mn>360</mn></mfrac></math> first, then multiply by <math><mi>π</mi><msup><mi>r</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></math>.

questions.question_chart_svg: <svg width='420' height='260' viewBox='0 0 420 260' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><rect width='420' height='260' fill='white'/><circle cx='210' cy='150' r='80' fill='none' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><circle cx='210' cy='150' r='3' fill='black'/><text x='195' y='160' font-size='14' font-family='serif'>O</text><line x1='210' y1='150' x2='290' y2='150' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><circle cx='290' cy='150' r='3' fill='black'/><text x='300' y='155' font-size='14' font-family='serif'>A</text><line x1='210' y1='150' x2='250' y2='80.7' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><circle cx='250' cy='80.7' r='3' fill='black'/><text x='255' y='75' font-size='14' font-family='serif'>B</text><path d='M 250 150 A 40 40 0 0 0 230 115.4' fill='none' stroke='black' stroke-width='1'/><text x='245' y='135' font-size='12'>60°</text><text x='250' y='170' font-size='12'>10</text><text x='215' y='110' font-size='12'>10</text></svg>
questions.question_chart_description: A circle with center O. Radius OA lies on the horizontal axis. Radius OB forms a 60-degree angle with OA. Both radii are labeled with length 10.
questions.question: In the figure, <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>O</mi></math> is the center of the circle, <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>O</mi><mi>A</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>O</mi><mi>B</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>10</mn></math>, and <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mo>∠</mo><mi>A</mi><mi>O</mi><mi>B</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>60</mn><mo>°</mo></math>. What is the length of chord <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>A</mi><mi>B</mi></math>?
questions.explanation: Since <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>O</mi><mi>A</mi></math> and <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>O</mi><mi>B</mi></math> are radii of the same circle, <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>O</mi><mi>A</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>O</mi><mi>B</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>10</mn></math>. This makes triangle <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>A</mi><mi>O</mi><mi>B</mi></math> an isosceles triangle. The vertex angle <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mo>∠</mo><mi>A</mi><mi>O</mi><mi>B</mi></math> is <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mn>60</mn><mo>°</mo></math>. The base angles must be equal and sum to <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mn>180</mn><mo>°</mo><mo>-</mo><mn>60</mn><mo>°</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>120</mn><mo>°</mo></math>. Therefore, each base angle is <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mn>60</mn><mo>°</mo></math>. A triangle with three <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mn>60</mn><mo>°</mo></math> angles is equilateral, so all sides are equal. Thus, the length of chord <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>A</mi><mi>B</mi></math> is <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mn>10</mn></math>.
questions.explanation_chart_svg: <svg width='420' height='260' viewBox='0 0 420 260' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><rect width='420' height='260' fill='white'/><polygon points='210,150 290,150 250,80.7' fill='none' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><line x1='290' y1='150' x2='250' y2='80.7' stroke='red' stroke-width='3'/><text x='195' y='160' font-family='serif'>O</text><text x='300' y='155' font-family='serif'>A</text><text x='255' y='75' font-family='serif'>B</text><text x='225' y='145' font-size='10'>60°</text><text x='270' y='145' font-size='10'>60°</text><text x='250' y='110' font-size='10'>60°</text><text x='280' y='115' font-size='14' fill='red' font-weight='bold'>10</text><text x='250' y='200' font-size='14' fill='blue'>Equilateral Triangle</text></svg>
questions.explanation_chart_description: Triangle AOB is shown with chord AB highlighted in red. All three angles are labeled 60°, demonstrating that the triangle is equilateral. Consequently, side AB is labeled 10, matching the radii.
questions.score_improvement_tip: If an isosceles triangle has a vertex angle of 60°, it is an equilateral triangle.

questions.question: In a circle, an inscribed angle intercepts an arc that measures <math><mn>110</mn><mo>°</mo></math>. What is the measure of the inscribed angle?
questions.explanation: An inscribed angle equals half the measure of its intercepted arc. So the angle measure is <math><mfrac><mn>110</mn><mn>2</mn></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mn>55</mn></math>, which is <math><mn>55</mn><mo>°</mo></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Use <math><mrow><mo>∠</mo><mi>A</mi></mrow><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mn>2</mn></mfrac><mo>(</mo><mtext>intercepted arc</mtext><mo>)</mo></math> for inscribed-angle problems.

questions.question_chart_svg: <svg width='420' height='300' viewBox='0 0 420 300' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><rect width='420' height='300' fill='white'/><circle cx='210' cy='150' r='80' fill='none' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><circle cx='210' cy='150' r='3' fill='black'/><text x='195' y='160' font-size='14' font-family='serif'>O</text><circle cx='290' cy='150' r='3' fill='black'/><text x='300' y='155' font-size='14' font-family='serif'>P</text><circle cx='223.9' cy='71.2' r='3' fill='black'/><text x='220' y='60' font-size='14' font-family='serif'>Q</text><line x1='210' y1='150' x2='290' y2='150' stroke='black' stroke-width='1'/><line x1='210' y1='150' x2='223.9' y2='71.2' stroke='black' stroke-width='1'/><line x1='290' y1='150' x2='223.9' y2='71.2' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><line x1='290' y1='50' x2='290' y2='250' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><text x='300' y='240' font-size='12'>Tangent</text><path d='M 270 150 A 60 60 0 0 0 220.4 90.9' fill='none' stroke='black'/><text x='245' y='130' font-size='12'>80°</text><path d='M 290 110 A 40 40 0 0 0 263 122' fill='none' stroke='black' stroke-dasharray='4'/><text x='275' y='105' font-size='14' font-weight='bold'>?</text></svg>
questions.question_chart_description: A circle with center O. A vertical tangent line touches the circle at the rightmost point P. A chord connects P to point Q on the circle. The central angle POQ is marked as 80°. The angle between the tangent line and the chord PQ is marked with a question mark.
questions.question: In the figure, a line is tangent to the circle at point <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>P</mi></math>, and chord <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>P</mi><mi>Q</mi></math> is drawn. If the measure of arc <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>P</mi><mi>Q</mi></math> is <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mn>80</mn><mo>°</mo></math>, what is the measure of the angle formed by the tangent line and the chord <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>P</mi><mi>Q</mi></math> at <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>P</mi></math>?
questions.explanation: According to the Tangent-Chord Theorem, the measure of an angle formed by a tangent and a chord meeting at the point of tangency is one-half the measure of the intercepted arc. The intercepted arc <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>P</mi><mi>Q</mi></math> measures <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mn>80</mn><mo>°</mo></math>. Therefore, the angle formed is <math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mn>2</mn></mfrac><mo>(</mo><mn>80</mn><mo>°</mo><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>40</mn><mo>°</mo></math>.
questions.explanation_chart_svg: <svg width='420' height='300' viewBox='0 0 420 300' xmlns='http://www.w3.org/2000/svg'><rect width='420' height='300' fill='white'/><circle cx='210' cy='150' r='80' fill='none' stroke='lightgray' stroke-width='2'/><line x1='210' y1='150' x2='290' y2='150' stroke='black' stroke-width='1'/><line x1='210' y1='150' x2='223.9' y2='71.2' stroke='black' stroke-width='1'/><line x1='290' y1='50' x2='290' y2='250' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><line x1='290' y1='150' x2='223.9' y2='71.2' stroke='black' stroke-width='2'/><path d='M 290 150 A 80 80 0 0 0 223.9 71.2' fill='none' stroke='red' stroke-width='3'/><text x='260' y='90' font-size='12' fill='red'>Arc = 80°</text><path d='M 290 110 A 40 40 0 0 0 263 122' fill='none' stroke='blue' stroke-width='2'/><text x='270' y='100' font-size='12' fill='blue' font-weight='bold'>Angle = 40°</text><text x='195' y='160' font-family='serif'>O</text><text x='300' y='155' font-family='serif'>P</text><text x='220' y='60' font-family='serif'>Q</text></svg>
questions.explanation_chart_description: The chart highlights the intercepted arc PQ in red (80°) and the angle between the tangent and chord in blue (40°), visually demonstrating the theorem that the angle is half the arc.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Recall the Tangent-Chord Theorem: The angle between a tangent and a chord through the point of contact is equal to half the measure of the intercepted arc (<math xmlns='http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML'><mi>Angle</mi><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mn>2</mn></mfrac><mi>Arc</mi></math>).

questions.question: A circle in the <math><mi>x</mi><mi>y</mi></math>-plane is defined by <math><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><msup><mi>y</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>-</mo><mn>6</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>8</mn><mi>y</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>9</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math>. What are the coordinates of the center of the circle?
questions.explanation: Group terms and complete the square: <math><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>-</mo><mn>6</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><msup><mi>y</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><mn>8</mn><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mo>-</mo><mn>9</mn></math>. Then <math><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>-</mo><mn>6</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>9</mn><mo>=</mo><msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow><mn>2</mn></msup></math> and <math><msup><mi>y</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><mn>8</mn><mi>y</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>16</mn><mo>=</mo><msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>y</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>4</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow><mn>2</mn></msup></math>. Adding <math><mn>9</mn></math> and <math><mn>16</mn></math> to both sides gives <math><msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>y</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>4</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>=</mo><mn>16</mn></math>. The center is <math><mo>(</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>,</mo><mo>-</mo><mn>4</mn><mo>)</mo></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: To find a circle’s center from general form, complete the square for both <math><mi>x</mi></math> and <math><mi>y</mi></math>.

questions.question: A circle has area <math><mn>49</mn><mi>π</mi></math>. What is the diameter of the circle? Enter your answer as an integer.
questions.explanation: Use <math><mi>A</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>π</mi><msup><mi>r</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></math>. Set <math><mn>49</mn><mi>π</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>π</mi><msup><mi>r</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></math> and cancel <math><mi>π</mi></math> to get <math><msup><mi>r</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>=</mo><mn>49</mn></math>, so <math><mi>r</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>7</mn></math>. The diameter is <math><mn>2</mn><mi>r</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>14</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: After finding <math><mi>r</mi></math>, remember that diameter is <math><mn>2</mn><mi>r</mi></math>.

questions.question: A circle has equation <math><msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>y</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>5</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>=</mo><mn>25</mn></math>. The circle is tangent to the <math><mi>x</mi></math>-axis. Which statement best describes the tangency point?

options.A: It occurs at the top of the circle.
options.B: It occurs at the bottom of the circle.
options.C: It occurs on the rightmost point of the circle.
options.D: It occurs on the leftmost point of the circle.

questions.explanation: The center is <math><mo>(</mo><mo>-</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>5</mn><mo>)</mo></math> and the radius is <math><msqrt><mn>25</mn></msqrt><mo>=</mo><mn>5</mn></math>. The distance from the center to the <math><mi>x</mi></math>-axis is <math><mn>5</mn></math>, which equals the radius, so the circle is tangent to the axis at its bottom point.
questions.score_improvement_tip: For tangency to an axis, compare the center’s distance to that axis with the radius.

questions.question: For what positive value of <math><mi>k</mi></math> is the line <math><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>k</mi></math> tangent to the circle <math><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><msup><mi>y</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>=</mo><mn>36</mn></math>?
questions.explanation: The circle <math><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><msup><mi>y</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>=</mo><mn>36</mn></math> has center <math><mo>(</mo><mn>0</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>0</mn><mo>)</mo></math> and radius <math><msqrt><mn>36</mn></msqrt><mo>=</mo><mn>6</mn></math>. The line <math><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>k</mi></math> is horizontal and is tangent exactly when its distance from the origin equals the radius, so <math><mrow><mo>|</mo><mi>k</mi><mo>|</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mn>6</mn></math>. From the choices, <math><mi>k</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>6</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: A line is tangent to a circle when the perpendicular distance from the center to the line equals the radius.

questions.question: A circle passes through the points <math><mo>(</mo><mn>0</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>0</mn><mo>)</mo></math>, <math><mo>(</mo><mn>6</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>0</mn><mo>)</mo></math>, and <math><mo>(</mo><mn>0</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>8</mn><mo>)</mo></math>. What is the radius of the circle?
questions.explanation: Use the form <math><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><msup><mi>y</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><mi>D</mi><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>E</mi><mi>y</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>F</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math>. Substituting <math><mo>(</mo><mn>0</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>0</mn><mo>)</mo></math> gives <math><mi>F</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math>. Substituting <math><mo>(</mo><mn>6</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>0</mn><mo>)</mo></math> gives <math><mn>36</mn><mo>+</mo><mn>6</mn><mi>D</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math>, so <math><mi>D</mi><mo>=</mo><mo>-</mo><mn>6</mn></math>. Substituting <math><mo>(</mo><mn>0</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>8</mn><mo>)</mo></math> gives <math><mn>64</mn><mo>+</mo><mn>8</mn><mi>E</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math>, so <math><mi>E</mi><mo>=</mo><mo>-</mo><mn>8</mn></math>. The equation is <math><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><msup><mi>y</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>-</mo><mn>6</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>8</mn><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math>, which rewrites as <math><msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>y</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>4</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>=</mo><mn>25</mn></math>. Thus <math><msup><mi>r</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>=</mo><mn>25</mn></math> and <math><mi>r</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>5</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Three non-collinear points determine a unique circle; set up <math><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><msup><mi>y</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><mi>D</mi><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>E</mi><mi>y</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>F</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math> and solve for constants.

questions.question: Two chords intersect inside a circle. One chord intercepts an arc of measure <math><mn>150</mn><mo>°</mo></math>, and the other chord intercepts an arc of measure <math><mn>70</mn><mo>°</mo></math> (these are the arcs opposite the angle at the intersection). What is the measure of the angle formed by the two chords at their intersection?
questions.explanation: For two chords intersecting inside a circle, the angle measure equals half the sum of the measures of the intercepted arcs. So the angle is <math><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mn>2</mn></mfrac><mo>(</mo><mn>150</mn><mo>+</mo><mn>70</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mn>2</mn></mfrac><mo>(</mo><mn>220</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>110</mn></math>, or <math><mn>110</mn><mo>°</mo></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: For intersecting chords inside a circle, use <math><mrow><mo>∠</mo><mi>E</mi></mrow><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mn>1</mn><mn>2</mn></mfrac><mo>(</mo><mtext>arc</mtext><mo>+</mo><mtext>arc</mtext><mo>)</mo></math>.

questions.question: Circle A is defined by <math><msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>y</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>4</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>=</mo><mn>49</mn></math>. Circle B is obtained by shifting Circle A <math><mn>5</mn></math> units left and <math><mn>6</mn></math> units up. If Circle B is written as <math><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><msup><mi>y</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><mn>8</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>4</mn><mi>y</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>c</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math>, what is the value of <math><mi>c</mi></math>? Enter your answer as an integer.
questions.explanation: Circle A has center <math><mo>(</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>,</mo><mo>-</mo><mn>4</mn><mo>)</mo></math> and radius <math><mn>7</mn></math> because <math><msup><mi>r</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>=</mo><mn>49</mn></math>. Shifting left <math><mn>5</mn></math> and up <math><mn>6</mn></math> gives the new center <math><mo>(</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>-</mo><mn>5</mn><mo>,</mo><mo>-</mo><mn>4</mn><mo>+</mo><mn>6</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mo>(</mo><mo>-</mo><mn>4</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>)</mo></math>. So Circle B is <math><msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>4</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>y</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>2</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>=</mo><mn>49</mn></math>. Expanding gives <math><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><mn>8</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>16</mn><mo>+</mo><msup><mi>y</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>-</mo><mn>4</mn><mi>y</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>4</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>49</mn></math>, so <math><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><msup><mi>y</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><mn>8</mn><mi>x</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>4</mn><mi>y</mi><mo>-</mo><mn>29</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math>. Therefore <math><mi>c</mi><mo>=</mo><mo>-</mo><mn>29</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Apply translations to the center first, then expand to match the requested general form.

questions.question: A circle is tangent to both coordinate axes and has its center in the first quadrant. The circle passes through the point <math><mo>(</mo><mn>6</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>8</mn><mo>)</mo></math>. If the radius is less than <math><mn>10</mn></math>, what is the radius of the circle?
questions.explanation: If the circle is tangent to both axes and the center is in the first quadrant, then the center is <math><mo>(</mo><mi>r</mi><mo>,</mo><mi>r</mi><mo>)</mo></math>. Since <math><mo>(</mo><mn>6</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>8</mn><mo>)</mo></math> is on the circle, <math><msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>6</mn><mo>-</mo><mi>r</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mn>8</mn><mo>-</mo><mi>r</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>=</mo><msup><mi>r</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></math>. Expanding gives <math><mn>36</mn><mo>-</mo><mn>12</mn><mi>r</mi><mo>+</mo><msup><mi>r</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><mn>64</mn><mo>-</mo><mn>16</mn><mi>r</mi><mo>+</mo><msup><mi>r</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>=</mo><msup><mi>r</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></math>, so <math><mn>100</mn><mo>-</mo><mn>28</mn><mi>r</mi><mo>+</mo><msup><mi>r</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math>. Solving <math><msup><mi>r</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>-</mo><mn>28</mn><mi>r</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>100</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math> gives <math><mi>r</mi><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mn>28</mn><mn>2</mn></mfrac><mo>±</mo><mfrac><msqrt><mn>784</mn><mo>-</mo><mn>400</mn></msqrt><mn>2</mn></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mn>14</mn><mo>±</mo><mfrac><msqrt><mn>384</mn></msqrt><mn>2</mn></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mn>14</mn><mo>±</mo><mn>4</mn><msqrt><mn>6</mn></msqrt></math>. The smaller radius is <math><mn>14</mn><mo>-</mo><mn>4</mn><msqrt><mn>6</mn></msqrt></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: For circles tangent to both axes in the first quadrant, the center is <math><mo>(</mo><mi>r</mi><mo>,</mo><mi>r</mi><mo>)</mo></math>.

questions.question: Two concentric circles have radii <math><mi>r</mi></math> and <math><mi>r</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>3</mn></math>. The difference between their areas is <math><mn>39</mn><mi>π</mi></math>. What is the value of <math><mi>r</mi></math>? Enter your answer as an integer.
questions.explanation: The area difference is <math><mi>π</mi><msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>r</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>-</mo><mi>π</mi><msup><mi>r</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>=</mo><mi>π</mi><mo>(</mo><msup><mi>r</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><mn>6</mn><mi>r</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>9</mn><mo>-</mo><msup><mi>r</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mi>π</mi><mo>(</mo><mn>6</mn><mi>r</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>9</mn><mo>)</mo></math>. Set <math><mi>π</mi><mo>(</mo><mn>6</mn><mi>r</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>9</mn><mo>)</mo><mo>=</mo><mn>39</mn><mi>π</mi></math> and cancel <math><mi>π</mi></math> to get <math><mn>6</mn><mi>r</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>9</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>39</mn></math>. Then <math><mn>6</mn><mi>r</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>30</mn></math> and <math><mi>r</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>5</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Expand <math><msup><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>r</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>3</mn><mo>)</mo></mrow><mn>2</mn></msup></math> carefully to avoid missing the <math><mn>6</mn><mi>r</mi></math> term.

questions.question: From a point <math><mi>P</mi></math> outside a circle, a tangent segment <math><mover><mi>P</mi><mi>T</mi></mover></math> has length <math><mn>12</mn></math>. A secant from <math><mi>P</mi></math> intersects the circle at <math><mi>A</mi></math> and <math><mi>B</mi></math> with <math><mi>P</mi><mi>A</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>8</mn></math>. What is the length of <math><mi>P</mi><mi>B</mi></math>?
questions.explanation: By the tangent-secant theorem (power of a point), <math><mi>P</mi><msup><mi>T</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>=</mo><mi>P</mi><mi>A</mi><mo>·</mo><mi>P</mi><mi>B</mi></math>. Substitute <math><mi>P</mi><mi>T</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>12</mn></math> and <math><mi>P</mi><mi>A</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>8</mn></math>: <math><msup><mn>12</mn><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>=</mo><mn>8</mn><mo>·</mo><mi>P</mi><mi>B</mi></math>. Then <math><mn>144</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>8</mn><mi>P</mi><mi>B</mi></math> and <math><mi>P</mi><mi>B</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>18</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: For tangents and secants from the same external point, use <math><msup><mi>t</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>=</mo><mi>e</mi><mo>(</mo><mi>e</mi><mo>+</mo><mi>i</mi><mo>)</mo></math> or the equivalent <math><mi>P</mi><msup><mi>T</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>=</mo><mi>P</mi><mi>A</mi><mo>·</mo><mi>P</mi><mi>B</mi></math>.

questions.question: A chord of a circle has length <math><mn>16</mn></math>. The perpendicular distance from the center of the circle to the chord is <math><mn>6</mn></math>. What is the radius of the circle? Enter your answer as an integer.
questions.explanation: The perpendicular from the center to a chord bisects the chord, so half the chord length is <math><mfrac><mn>16</mn><mn>2</mn></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mn>8</mn></math>. A right triangle is formed with legs <math><mn>6</mn></math> and <math><mn>8</mn></math> and hypotenuse <math><mi>r</mi></math>. Thus <math><msup><mi>r</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>=</mo><msup><mn>6</mn><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><msup><mn>8</mn><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>=</mo><mn>36</mn><mo>+</mo><mn>64</mn><mo>=</mo><mn>100</mn></math>, so <math><mi>r</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>10</mn></math>.
questions.score_improvement_tip: Use the fact that a radius perpendicular to a chord bisects the chord, creating a right triangle.

questions.question: For which positive value of <math><mi>m</mi></math> is the line <math><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>m</mi><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>6</mn></math> tangent to the circle <math><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><msup><mi>y</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>=</mo><mn>25</mn></math>?
questions.explanation: The circle has center <math><mo>(</mo><mn>0</mn><mo>,</mo><mn>0</mn><mo>)</mo></math> and radius <math><mn>5</mn></math>. The distance from the origin to the line <math><mi>y</mi><mo>=</mo><mi>m</mi><mi>x</mi><mo>+</mo><mn>6</mn></math> equals <math><mfrac><mrow><mrow><mo>|</mo><mn>6</mn><mo>|</mo></mrow></mrow><msqrt><msup><mi>m</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><mn>1</mn></msqrt></mfrac></math>. Tangency requires <math><mfrac><mn>6</mn><msqrt><msup><mi>m</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><mn>1</mn></msqrt></mfrac><mo>=</mo><mn>5</mn></math>. So <math><msqrt><msup><mi>m</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><mn>1</mn></msqrt><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mn>6</mn><mn>5</mn></mfrac></math>, and squaring gives <math><msup><mi>m</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>+</mo><mn>1</mn><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mn>36</mn><mn>25</mn></mfrac></math>. Then <math><msup><mi>m</mi><mn>2</mn></msup><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mn>11</mn><mn>25</mn></mfrac></math>, so <math><mi>m</mi><mo>=</mo><mfrac><msqrt><mn>11</mn></msqrt><mn>5</mn></mfrac></math> (a matching choice).
questions.score_improvement_tip: To test tangency, set the distance from the circle’s center to the line equal to the radius.
